Antioch, a bustling city in the ancient world, emerged as a pivotal hub for early Christianity. This city, known for its diverse population of Gentiles, played a significant role as the first sending church. It was in Antioch that the Holy Spirit set apart Paul and Barnabas for missionary work, as the church fervently prayed for their mission's success. The community at Antioch consecrated these chosen ones by laying hands on them, signaling their commitment to support and send them on their journey to spread the gospel and establish new churches.

As a redemptive organism closely tied to the Church, Paul and Barnabas received both financial and spiritual support from Antioch. Recognizing the importance of autonomy within the missionary group, the church upheld their connection while allowing for independence in fulfilling their mission. This arrangement enabled them to plant indigenous churches under the Holy Spirit's guidance, with accountability to both Antioch and Jerusalem.

Antioch's commitment to global missions bore fruit, leading to swift growth and further opportunities for commissioning missionaries. The Church at Antioch understood the significance of engaging in both local and global missions, highlighting the ongoing calling for churches to send and be sent by the Holy Spirit. This divine calling requires complete dependence on the Spirit for guidance, empowerment, and ultimate success in spreading the gospel.

"God is our refuge and strength, an ever-present help in trouble." (Psalm 46:1) As the Church today reflects on the example set by Antioch, may we embrace the Spirit's leading with faith and obedience, recognizing our role in fulfilling the Great Commission. Just as Antioch exemplified, we are called to be active participants in the redemptive work of God, sending and being sent with purpose and conviction.

“Because I wanted to give you the advantage of your own skates.”

“Are you willing to have a second trial, in which I use Harry’s skates?”

If Rupert had been prudent he would have made some excuse for declining, but I have already said that he was self-conceited about his skating, and he really believed that he could skate faster than Tom. In the event of a second trial, he would have a chance to show this. After slight hesitation, therefore, he said:

“Yes; I’ll try again, just to satisfy you.”

It was decided to start from the further end of the pond, and again Harry Julian was selected to give the word.

“Are you ready?” he asked.

“Yes,” answered both boys.

“Then--go!”

This time both started together.

At equal speed they dashed out for the opposite shore. Tom was fresher than his rival, and he was not now obliged to exert himself as in the former race. Indeed, he kept himself partly in check, not caring to pass Rupert till they neared the end of the race, for he feared that when the latter found himself hopelessly in the rear he would again manage to stumble, and so deprive him of the laurels he had justly won.

Of course the boys who were looking on did not know this, and when they saw Tom and Rupert skating side by side when the race was three-quarters over, they watched with great excitement, uncertain which would win.

Now the race was seven-eighths over, and still the boys were skating side by side. It was difficult to tell which was ahead.

Rupert’s breath came quick and short. Only a little ahead was the goal, and there seemed as good a chance of his reaching it as of Tom’s doing so.

“Anyway, we shall come in together,” he thought, “and then the pegger boy can’t triumph over me.”

This would not be quite as well as winning the race, but it would certainly be a great deal better than being defeated.

But Rupert made no account of Tom’s reserved strength. Even as this thought passed through his mind, Tom made a brilliant spurt, and before Rupert fairly realized the situation, his rival had touched the goal, leaving him fifty feet behind.

He reddened with anger and mortification, utterly unable to devise any excuse for his failure.

At a little distance behind were the other skaters.

“That was a pretty race,” said Harry, as he came up. “I suppose you’ll admit that you are beaten, now, Rupert. Come, own up,” said Harry, seeing that Rupert remained silent. “You can’t deny that that was a fair race.”

“He wouldn’t have beaten me if I had been well,” said Rupert, thinking of an excuse at last.

“If you had been well?”

“Yes, that’s what I said.”

“What’s the matter with you?”

“I’ve got a bad headache. I thought of stopping in the middle of the race, but I didn’t want to spoil it.”

There was not a boy within hearing who believed for a moment that Rupert was really troubled with a headache, so that his subterfuge was of no service to him.

“Your headache came on rather suddenly, didn’t it?” asked Harry, significantly.

“No; I’ve had it for half an hour.”

“When the race was first proposed did you have it?”

“Yes.”

“Why didn’t you say so?”

“I thought it might not interfere with me.”

“Then I suppose you don’t consider this a fair race?”

“Of course not. How can a fellow skate well when he’s got a splitting headache?”

“Would you have said anything about the headache if you had won?”

“Look here, Harry Julian, I don’t like the way you talk. If you mean to insult me say so at once.”

“I don’t care to insult anyone,” said Harry, coldly. “Since you don’t consider this a fair race I presume Tom will be willing to race you any time you may appoint. You can wait till you are in perfect health.”

Horatio Alger, Jr., an author who lived among and for boys and himself remained a boy in heart and association till death, was born at Revere, Mass., January 18, 1884. He was the son of a clergyman; was graduated at Harvard College in 1852, and at its Divinity School in 1860; and was pastor of the Unitarian Church at Brewster, Mass., in 1862-66. In the latter year he settled in New York and began drawing public attention to the condition and needs of street boys. He mingled with them, gained their confidence, showed a personal concern in their affairs, and stimulated them to honest and useful living. With his first story he won the hearts of all red-blooded boys every-where, and of the seventy or more that followed over a million copies were sold during the author's lifetime.

In his later life he was in appearance a short, stout, bald-headed man, with cordial manners and whimsical views of things that amused all who met him. He died at Natick, Mass., July 18, 1899.

Mr. Alger's stories are as popular now as when first published, because they treat of real live boys who were always up and about--just like the boys found everywhere to-day. They are pure in tone and inspiring in influence, and many reforms in the juvenile life of New York may be traced to them. Among the best known are:

Strong and Steady; Strive and Succeed; Try and Trust: Bound to Rise; Risen from the Ranks; Herbert Carter's Legacy; Brave and Bold; Jack's Ward; Shifting for Himself; Wait and Hope; Paul the Peddler; Phil the Fiddler: Slow and Sure: Julius the Street Boy; Tom the Bootblack; Struggling Upward; Facing the World; The Cash Boy; Making His Way; Tony the Tramp; Joe's Luck; Do and Dare: Only an Irish Boy; Sink or Swim; A Cousin's Conspiracy; Andy Gordon; Bob Burton; Harry Vane; Hector's Inheritance; Mark Manson's Triumph; Sam's Chance; The Telegraph Boy; The Young Adventurer; The Young Outlaw; The Young Salesman, and Luke Walton..

"Sit up to the table, children, breakfast's ready."

The speaker was a woman of middle age, not good-looking in the ordinary acceptation of the term, but nevertheless she looked good. She was dressed with extreme plainness, in a cheap calico; but though cheap, the dress was neat. The children she addressed were six in number, varying in age from twelve to four. The oldest, Harry, the hero of the present story, was a broad-shouldered, sturdy boy, with a frank, open face, resolute, though good-natured.

"Father isn't here," said Fanny, the second child.

"He'll be in directly. He went to the store, and he may stop as he comes back to milk."

The table was set in the center of the room, covered with a coarse tablecloth. The breakfast provided was hardly of a kind to tempt an epicure. There was a loaf of bread cut into slices, and a dish of boiled potatoes. There was no butter and no meat, for the family were very poor.

The children sat up to the table and began to eat. They were blessed with good appetites, and did not grumble, as the majority of my readers would have done, at the scanty fare. They had not been accustomed to anything better, and their appetites were not pampered by indulgence.

They had scarcely commenced the meal when the father entered. Like his wife, he was coarsely dressed. In personal appearance he resembled his oldest boy. His wife looking up as he entered perceived that he looked troubled.

"What is the matter, Hiram?" she asked. "You look as if something had happened."

"Nothing has happened yet," he answered; "but I am afraid we are going to lose the cow."

Hastiin and the other Protectors linger at the periphery of the Sixth world like spectral forms of memory, their heroic deeds against external threats now fading into irrelevance against internal dangers such as environmental degradation. Once celebrated as guardians of the Fifth world, their faces—lined with age and etched by windblown sand—bear silent testimony to a bygone era when defending the Earth was synonymous with confronting external adversaries rather than examining internal negligence. From the sun-scorched mesas of Black Mesa, where dust clouds rise eerily from scarred earth and toxic runoff trickles quietly into rivers, the environmental challenges of the Sixth world steadily manifest. Indigenous communities, deeply connected by cultural memory to this land, witness helplessly as ancestral territories continue to suffer from unchecked exploitation. Maggie and Kai, though critical of the capitalist forces driving ecological harm, stay noticeably restrained, their rebellion contained within whispered frustrations and rueful discussions around campfires. As night falls beneath immense skies that shimmer with hints of stars partially obscured by industrial haze, Maggie reflects quietly upon the ironies within this new order; capitalism persists, altered but unwavering, promising progress while perpetuating invisible wounds upon the earth. Kai listens quietly, deeply aware of the contradiction embedded in their inaction, of the irony that even conscious critique has not translated into tangible resistance against corrupted officials whose greed perpetuates the Earth's distress.

Yet amidst his introspective silences, Kai emerges as a bearer of possibility, symbolizing hope intertwined with ancestral wisdom. Tah, wise and patient, suggests quietly that Kai holds within him clan powers rooted in the land itself—gifts that carry the potential of healing environmental wounds inflicted both before and after the catastrophic rise of the Big Water. This assertion positions Kai as a revised iteration of the "ecological Indian," stripped away of romanticized stereotypes of effortless harmony and recast as someone acutely aware of survival's relationship with environmental stewardship. He embodies the tension between hopeful potential and harsh reality; though capable of healing, he recognizes that no force within him could ever restore the Earth to its earlier glory, untouched and unmarred by humanity's transgressions. Kai's awareness sharpens against comparisons between past and present, between the protective spirit that animated Hastiin and his fellow Protectors and their present-day impotence. The Protectors witness Black Mesa's wounds without action, their protective gaze once outward aimed at external dangers now unrelated to internal threats posed by corporate exploitation and systemic neglect. Indigenous visions of ecological responsibility expand beyond stable myths of idyllic conservation into complex realities of survival amidst a deeply flawed capitalist structure. Kai stands at this crossroad, embodying simultaneously lament and promise—mourning the inability to recover fully what was lost to the waters, yet conscious of present opportunities to halt, mitigate, and maybe even heal. Indigenous communities, portrayed as resilient architects of potent solutions, increasingly recognize the necessity of addressing the wounds left upon the land, not viewing this responsibility through simplistic tropes but rather as an active fight for their futures, acknowledging damage both internal and external as requiring committed responses. Amidst polluted landscapes and fading traditions, Kai quietly embraces his identity not as an idealized ecological savior but as part of a generation entrusted with healing and renewal, symbolizing a nuanced hope that the transition from the Fifth world into the Sixth, though fraught, might yet yield meaningful reconnections between humanity and Earth.

The evening shadows stretched long and thin across the forest floor as Kate gathered her cloak about her shoulders, casting a final glance around their little camp. The air was growing crisp, and a faint rustle whispered through the trees, as if urging her to be on her way. She tucked a tendril of hair behind her ear, brushing off the small twigs and leaves that had gathered during her unplanned nap. As she peered into the waning light, the path winding homeward seemed longer, more uncertain.

She left the note for Harry, a simple line scribbled quickly on the back of an old envelope: "Gone to the house. Be careful!" She placed it under a round stone, hoping its weight would keep the scrap from fluttering away before Harry's return. She hesitated then, wishing she could be certain he would find it, imagining his expression when he returned to camp, finding neither her nor a clue to her whereabouts in the forest’s gloom.

As she walked, Kate reviewed their discoveries of the day in her mind—plums and blackberries, each gleaming like jewels among the leaves, and the arrowhead, which she yearned to examine more closely. She smiled at the thought of it all, wondering if one day those plums would find their way into her mother's pantry, jarred and preserved as kindly mementos of the wild. Her mind strayed to the sumac leaves she had diligently gathered, carefully considering their worth and imagining what she might someday purchase with their sale.

The sound of the crickets enveloped her, a comforting orchestra as she trod the well-worn trail. The branches above interwove like delicate lace, casting patches of light upon her path whenever the moon managed to break through the gathering clouds. She stepped over roots and around brambles, her eyes adjusted to the dimness, and her heart stirred with an odd mix of vigilance and hope.

Nearing the bend where the forest opened onto familiar fields, Kate paused. Her thoughts lingered on Harry, on how he had set off so eagerly to identify the tracks they’d discovered. She recalled the youthful curiosity in his eyes, the way his face lit up at the prospect of finding some creature that might prove both novel and valuable. Would he emerge triumphant, proudly displaying a pelt or some other prize which would gladden their hearts and their pockets?

As if in answer to her thoughts, a sound in the underbrush made her pause. But it was only a rabbit, darting across the path into the shadowy thicket beyond. She laughed softly to herself, realizing she had let her imagination run wild. Kate pushed onward, determined now to reach home before the darkness fully embraced the land.

The cottage came into view, a welcome silhouette against the sky. Kate's relief was palpable as she stepped into the warm glow of the lantern-lit kitchen, her mother already setting a kettle to boil. The familiar comforts of home—fragrant herbs drying in the corner, the crackle of the fire—enfolded her as she explained Harry's prolonged absence and her own slow journey back.

Her mother listened, eyes flickering with concern, yet said nothing. Instead, she doted on Kate with the care a summer sun gives to a ripening field, ensuring both warmth and security. Over steaming cups of tea, Kate recounted the day, her words mingling with the steam that curled upwards like tendrils of thought unspooling into the air.

As the tale unfolded, her mother nodded knowingly, her hands working deftly with knitting needles, sculpting each row as if casting a silent spell for a safe return. Occasionally, she offered reassurances, her voice soft yet firm, like the lull of the branches outside. "He'll be home soon enough," she said, with a certainty that Kate wished she could fully embrace.

The hours wore on, and as the moon climbed higher, Kate fought off the worry that nestled in the pit of her stomach. Her gaze flitted repeatedly to the window, watching, waiting, while shadows shifted like phantoms across the panes. She stood there, the chill from the glass creeping into her bones, longing for a sign—any sign—of Harry's approach.

Despite her mother's gentle urging to rest, Kate remained steadfast by the window, unwilling to leave her post. Her eyes wandered from the familiar silhouette of the maple in the yard to the untamed horizon beyond, searching for her brother's form among the earth and stars. And so, the quiet vigil stretched into night, each minute a thread, binding hope and fear like fibers intertwined.

Brady-led Buccaneers Make Super Bowl History, Crediting Team Effort

GREEN BAY, Wis. – Tom Brady and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers made history on Sunday, defeating the Green Bay Packers 31-26 in the NFC Championship to secure a spot in Super Bowl 55. While Brady could have easily taken credit for the team's success, he deflected personal accolades, emphasizing the collective effort and journey of the Buccaneers.

"It's not just about me," Brady said after the game. "It's about this entire team and the hard work we've put in all season. We've had our ups and downs, but we've always found a way to come together and make plays when it matters most."

Brady's leadership and guidance have been instrumental in transforming the Buccaneers from a team with the NFC's longest playoff drought into a Super Bowl contender. In his first season with the team, he has brought a level of expertise and professionalism that has inspired his teammates and coaches alike.

"Tom has been a game-changer for us," said Buccaneers head coach Bruce Arians. "He's brought a level of intensity and passion to our team that we haven't seen before. He's a true leader and a great teammate, and we're lucky to have him."

Brady's move to Tampa Bay last season was seen as a lateral move by some, but he quickly proved that he was seeking a new challenge. He found a supportive environment in Tampa, where he was able to flourish and lead the team to success.

"I wanted a new challenge, and I found it in Tampa," Brady said. "The support from the organization and my teammates has been incredible, and it's shown in the way we've played this season."

The Buccaneers' offensive talent and defensive strength have complemented Brady's skills and leadership, allowing them to overcome midseason struggles and end the season on a winning streak.

"We've had our ups and downs, but we've always found a way to come together and make plays when it matters most," said wide receiver Scotty Miller. "Tom's leadership and guidance have been invaluable, and we're grateful to have him on our side."

Defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul and linebacker Jordan Whitehead also praised Brady's influence on the team.

"Tom's a true leader, and he's brought a level of intensity and passion to our team that we haven't seen before," Pierre-Paul said. "He's been a game-changer for us, and we're lucky to have him."

"Tom's leadership has been incredible, and it's shown in the way we've played this season," Whitehead added. "He's a true competitor, and he's brought out the best in all of us."

As the Buccaneers prepare to face the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl 55, they remain focused on their team-centric approach and the mutual benefit of Brady's move to Tampa Bay.

"We're not just a team, we're a family," Brady said. "And I'm proud to be a part of this family. We've worked too hard to get to this point to let anything get in our way."

The Buccaneers and Chiefs are set to face off in Super Bowl 55 on February 7, with kickoff scheduled for 6:30 p.m. ET. Despite the challenge ahead, the Buccaneers remain confident in their abilities and the strength of their team.

"We're ready for the challenge," Miller said. "We've worked too hard to get to this point to let anything get in our way. We're going to go out there and give it our all, and we're confident in our abilities."

This experience of racism is much different than that of past Asian immigrants, and coincides with a different experience of acculturation due to both the economic and racial climate. While Clutter’s family moved to an integrated area with a significant Asian population but also a significant non-Asian population, in the late 19th and early 20th century Chinese immigrants often moved to Chinatowns. Chinatowns were self-sustaining communities almost entirely occupied by Chinese immigrants and Chinese Americans. They operated their own businesses, maintained their own charities, and led an entire social, economic, and political life within Chinatown. This insulated Chinese immigrants and Americans from economic shocks such as the Depression but also mitigated the need for acculturation. Within Chinatown, people could speak Chinese, not learn English, and maintain cultural traditions from China without interference from non-Chinese Americans. These allowed Chinese immigrants to sustain their culture in America, but not only did it make it more difficult for them to interact outside of Chinatown, it made it more difficult to maintain Chinese culture after they did venture outside of Chinatown. Chinatown drew an either/or dichotomy between Chinese and American cultures. Although Chinese Americans did eventually come out of Chinatown to influence and be influenced by American culture, this was a long and difficult process. In contrast, since Clutter lived in an integrated area, the process of acculturation began immediately, and he still had the comfort of a large Asian community to bolster his traditional culture. The different situations can be explained by economics, since residents of Chinatown often could not afford to live anywhere else while Clutter’s affluent family had many options, and also racial dynamics, since Chinese Americans in the past were sometimes restricted from living in white areas, while today such restrictions are illegal.

Mike Clutter’s experience of acculturation was, by his telling, much more pleasant than the historical narratives of acculturation told by immigration historians. To sum up these late 19th to mid 20th century narratives: White ethnics adopted racism in order to be accepted as white. Chinese immigrants took a very long time to produce a second generation, and until then stayed secluded in Chinatowns. Things were going (relatively) great for Japanese immigrants until everyone on the west coast got locked up in internment camps, and they started to question how American they really were. Filipino immigrants adopted white Christian values and were then murdered by white Christians. Mexican immigrants were kicked out during the Depression, got a special category of “illegal” all for themselves, and then all of them were treated as badly as the illegal ones, even the middle-class Americanized immigrants with papers. In contrast, Mike Clutter, as previously mentioned, claims that racism has not affected his life.

This is not to imply that negotiating cultural boundaries is easy or simple, but it is apparently much easier than doing so in the face of huge racist obstacles.

He appears comfortable with both his adopted American culture and his traditional Taiwanese culture, although like anyone, he has had to make some choices. For Clutter, acculturation is primarily an internal struggle with few external obstacles, while immigrants of the late 19th to mid 20th century faced both serious internal and external struggles.

"Just step outside with Bunt a minute, my man," said Captain Asy Bean, "and we'll settle your case." Then, as the door closed behind the smiling criminal and his gloomy guardian, Captain Asy turned to the others:

"Gentlemen, this story may or may not be true. It sounds fishy; but, anyhow, the man must have come from somewhere, and I d'no as it matters much, s'long as he's here now. Question is, what to do with him now he is here. Just like them seleckmen, lettin' the jail go to rack an' ruin, an' then clappin' a man in thar for the sheep to nibble."

"Man's a seaman, anyhow," said Captain Bije Tarbox. "Ought t' ha' been sent straight to us."

"That's so!" assented the captains all.

"Wal!" resumed Captain Asy, "'pears to me the straight thing is for us to send for the seleckmen--they'll be goin' by to dinner direckly, an' we can toll 'em in an' say to 'em--"

"Thar she blows!" sang out Captain Abram.

"Where away?" asked Captain Moses Packard.

"Weather bow!" was the reply; and then the talk went on again.

Palmyra Henshaw was sitting in her neat kitchen, with folded hands. The kettle was singing cheerfully, the cat was purring contentedly by the stove; but for once Miss Palmyra's mood did not chime in with the singing or the purring. She had sprained her ankle the day before, and it was now so painful, that, after dragging it about till her work was "done up" (for, land sakes! she couldn't sit down in the dirt; and her kitchen had to be cleaned up, if she did it on her hands and knees), she was fain now to sit down and put the offending member up on a chair.

She looked at the poor foot with great displeasure. It was badly swollen; she had had to put on a green carpet slipper, one of an old pair of her father's; and the contrast with her other foot, in its trim, well-blacked shoe, was anything but pleasant.

As she sat thus in silent discomfort, she heard the sound of the pump in the yard. Somebody was working the handle up and down with firm, regular strokes.

"Well, what next?" said Miss Palmyra, fretfully, peering out of the window and trying to gain a sight of the intruder. "I sh'd like to know who's at that pump without askin' leave or license. I left the pail out there, too, didn't I? Like as not it'll go, same as the hen did. I must get up!"--she made a motion to rise, but sank back with a groan. "My Land! Have I got to sit here and have my things stole without liftin' a finger?"

At the same moment she heard quick steps crossing the yard: the door opened, and a man entered, carrying a brimming pail of water. Miss Palmyra opened her mouth to shriek, but closed it again when the stranger smiled.

"Good eve!" said the man, who had black curls, gold rings in his ears, and the brightest eyes that ever were seen. "I come to do ze work."

"Work!" ejaculated Miss Palmyra, faintly.

"Ze shores!" explained the man, with a brilliant flash of eyes and teeth. "You have hurt ze foot? So peety! Look! I fill ze kettel--so! I bring ze wood--so!" (He was gone, and back again with an armful of wood before Miss Palmyra could trust her bewildered senses enough to know whether she was awake or dreaming.) "I fill up ze stofe--so! And next? It is a cow zat you haf? I milk her!" He swept a glance around the kitchen, seized with unerring instinct the right pail, and was gone again.

Miss Palmyra pinched herself, and opened and shut her eyes several times.

"I wonder if I'm goin' crazy!" she said. "I feel kinder light-headed."

She looked at the cat, who blinked quietly in return, and his calm air of tranquillity steadied her nerves. "If he'd been a tramp, he wouldn't ha' brought in that wood!" she said. "Would he, Eben?" The cat was named Ebenezer. Ebenezer purred assurance, and Miss Palmyra's spirits rose. "Like as not he's stayin' with some o' the neighbours!" she said. "Mis' Brewster's real kind: mebbe this is her nephew she was expectin', and she sent him in to help me. Well, I'm sure!" She twitched a little shawl over the carpet-slipper, and settled her neat collar and apron.

In Helen Oyeyemi's "White is for Witching," the exploration of mental illness is both profound and intricate, weaving through the narrative with elegance and depth. Oyeyemi employs metaphor and narrative prosthesis to illustrate the complexities of mental illness, particularly pica, among the Silver women, creating a multidimensional story that blurs the lines between reality and metaphorical horror. Through multiple narrators, the novel explores the pervasive nature of this illness as it is inextricably linked to the matrilineal lineage and the haunted Silver family home.

In the narrative, mental illness is primarily associated with female characters, emphasizing the haunting legacy passed down through the Silver lineage. The portrayal of mental illness as a metaphorical condition is compelling. It accentuates the sense of 'otherness' surrounding the Silver women, who are subjected to more scrutiny than their male counterparts. This scrutiny amplifies their isolation, reflecting broader societal patterns where women's mental illnesses are often scrutinized and othered.

Miranda, the central protagonist, embodies the intersection between mental illness and the uncanny. Her affliction with pica—an eating disorder characterized by the consumption of non-food items—serves as a symbolic tether to the past and the family home. Oyeyemi uses this disorder to underline Miranda's difference, and it becomes a poignant metaphor for the consuming nature of the Silver home itself. The house, imbued with its eerie sentience, 'consumes' the women of the family as they reach puberty, binding them to its ethereal grasp.

Oyeyemi's choice to highlight pica, traditionally associated with specific psychiatric and developmental disorders, enriches the narrative's metaphorical weight. The disorder's associations with pregnancy enhance the theme of femaleness linked to mental illness. This connection invites interpretations of the house as a living entity, one that demands nourishment from the very individuals it incarcerates, thereby emphasizing the complexity of maternal and feminine identity.

The juxtaposition between male and female characters is deliberate, showcasing the distinct experiences of mental illness across genders. While the male characters in "White is for Witching" remain largely unscathed by the house's malevolent influence, the women, conversely, become ensnared in a cycle of inherited madness. This disparity further underscores the narrative's exploration of femininity and the societal stigmas surrounding female mental illness.

Oyeyemi's use of metaphorical horror serves to enhance the unsettling atmosphere of the story, transforming the house into a character infused with agency and menace. As the women crumble beneath the weight of their inherited maladies, the reader is left to ponder the blurred boundaries between supernatural and psychological torment. The house thus becomes a symbol of generational trauma, one that requires the sacrifice of the Silver women to sustain its existence.

In employing unique disorders like pica, Oyeyemi distinguishes the Silver women as 'Other,' both to the reader and within the fictional realm of Dover, England. This sense of otherness permeates the narrative, offering a chilling commentary on the alienation experienced by those deemed different due to invisible ailments. The story challenges perceptions of mental illness as merely a personal affliction, instead framing it as a multifaceted and culturally embedded phenomenon.

In conclusion, Helen Oyeyemi's "White is for Witching" is a masterful exploration of the intertwining themes of mental illness, femininity, and horror. Through a tapestry of metaphor, narrative innovation, and haunting imagery, Oyeyemi crafts a disturbing yet compelling portrait of the Silver women. Their struggles with pica and the consuming nature of the ancestral home underscore their marked otherness, revealing broader truths about the stigmatization and inheritance of mental illness among women. In this richly layered narrative, mental illness is not only a metaphor but a living, breathing entity—one that devours and defines the lives of those it touches.

‘Inexperienced’ Armorer on Baldwin Set Raised Alarm Bells on Prior Film

There were previous concerns raised about the 24-year-old armorer who was hired on Alec Baldwin’s film Rust, with two production sources telling The Daily Beast that filming on the set of her last movie was briefly stopped after she allegedly gave a gun to an 11-year-old actress without checking it properly.

“She was a bit careless with the guns, waving it around every now and again,” said a source, who worked alongside armorer Hannah Gutierrez-Reed on the upcoming Nicolas Cage film, The Old Way. “There were a couple times she was loading the blanks and doing it in a fashion that we thought was unsafe.”

Gutierrez-Reed was identified in a Santa Fe Sheriff’s Office search warrant affidavit as the armorer on set when Baldwin was given a prop gun he believed was safe. Baldwin discharged the gun, fatally striking 42-year-old cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and injuring 48-year-old director Joel Souza. No charges have been brought but the sheriff’s office’s investigation is ongoing.

Sources on the Rust set have insisted the fatal accident was a result of failings from top to bottom, starting with the production’s low-budget and cost-cutting measures.

Gutierrez-Reed was described as being “inexperienced and green” by a Rust production source, who told The Daily Beast there were at least two previous incidents of guns being accidentally discharged by other crew members before Thursday’s tragic incident.

According to the Actors’ Equity Association’s guidelines, guns should be test-fired off stage before each use. “All loading of firearms must be done by the property master, armorer or experienced persons working under their direct supervision,” the association advises.

Two Rust production sources, who have both worked in the industry for decades, claim that assistant director Dave Halls, who is named in the search warrant affidavit as the person who handed the gun to Baldwin and said it was safe, should have also checked the weapons.

“He’s supposed to be our last line of defense and he failed us,” the first source said. “He’s the last person that’s supposed to look at that firearm.”

According to the affidavit, Gutierrez-Reed had placed three prop guns on a cart outside where the scene was being filmed, before Halls grabbed a revolver from the cart and gave it to Baldwin. Halls called out “cold gun!” on set, according to the affidavit.

The second production source told The Daily Beast that the first assistant director should be personally verifying whether a weapon is “hot” or “cold.” (A “cold gun” indicates there are no cartridges—including blanks—inside the firearm. A “hot gun” indicates the weapon is loaded with cartridges, either live ammunition or blank rounds.) “This check alone should’ve prevented this incident,” the person said.

The morning sun filtered through the heavy draperies of the drawing-room at Earlston, casting soft, golden bars across the polished mahogany surfaces. Mrs. Ochterlony sat by the window, a cup of tea in her hands, her thoughts drifting as they often did when the weight of the past pressed upon her. The mention of Old Sommerville the previous evening had left her mind in a pleasing state of confusion, a sensation she found oddly amusing. For years, she had grown accustomed to her husband’s complaints, his occasional bursts of spleen, and the peculiarities of his character. Yet, it was the unexpected references to their shared history that intrigued her most, as if the very foundation of their marriage was built upon secrets and half-remembered tales.

When Major Ochterlony entered the room, his tall, broad frame moving with the restless energy that seemed to define him, she set her cup aside and smiled. He returned the gesture with a look that was both affectionate and bemused, as though he were well-aware of the peculiar turn their conversation had taken the night before.

“Well,” she began, her voice light and teasing, “I suppose I shall have to take your word for it, my dear. Old Sommerville—assuming he is the same Sommerville you speak of—does seem to have taken an unusual hold over your thoughts. But do tell, what is it about him that has you in such a state?”

The Major paused, his gaze dropping to the carpet as though searching for the precise words. “It is... complicated, Mary,” he said at last, his tone softening. “You see, Sommerville was more than just a gardener. He was there—when we... when we first...” His voice trailed off, and he ran a hand through his thick, dark hair, a gesture that spoke of both frustration and regret.

Mary watched him with a mixture of curiosity and amusement. She had long since learned that her husband’s tirades, no matter how passionate, rarely held the malice she might have expected. Indeed, there was a certain charm in his peculiar combination of pride and self-deprecation, as though he were perpetually at odds with himself. “You mean, at our wedding?” she prompted gently, her eyes crinkling with the faintest hint of a smile.

“Yes,” he admitted, though not without a degree of reluctance. “He was the gardener at Earlston at the time, and, well, he was there. A witness, if you will. The only one, in fact, who remains. The others... they have all passed on, or moved away. And now Sommerville is gone as well.”

Mary tilted her head, her expression one of genuine puzzlement. “But why should that trouble you so? A gardener’s presence at a wedding is hardly an uncommon occurrence, and surely there were others—clergy, family, friends— who would have seen us joined. Why Sommerville, of all people?”

The Major’s jaw tightened, a sign that he was struggling to articulate the weight of his thoughts. “It is not Sommerville’s role as a witness that concerns me, Mary,” he said, his voice low and earnest. “It is the fact that he was the last. The last surviving witness to a... to a marriage that neither of us truly wanted. A marriage that was, in many ways, a false start.”

Mary’s smile faded, and for a moment, she regarded her husband with a thoughtful, almost serious expression. “A false start?” she repeated, her tone tinged with playful disbelief. “You make it sound as though we were pawns in some grand game of fate, Major. But surely you do not believe that? After all, we have a perfectly happy life here at Earlston. What else could we have hoped for?”

“It is not about happiness, Mary,” the Major said, his voice heavy with the weight of years. “Or, at least, not merely about happiness. It is about duty. About obligation. About the expectations placed upon us by our families, our society, and our own pride. Sommerville’s death... it feels as though a piece of the past hasclosed off, leaving us to confront the choices we made without the chance to amend them.”

Mary chuckled, a soft, melodic sound that bespoke her customary good humor. “Amend them? My dear, there is little to amend. Our marriage, flawed though it may have been in its beginnings, has grown into something far greater. And if Sommerville was there to witness it, well, perhaps his death is a sign that even he understood the importance of moving forward.”

The Major’s expression softened, and he crossed the room to take her hand. “You have a way of making everything seem more bearable, Mary,” he said, his voice tinged with a tenderness that was rare but deeply felt. “Perhaps you are right. Perhaps Sommerville’s passing is a reminder that the past, no matter how troublesome, cannot hold us indefinitely.”

“And perhaps,” Mary added with a mischievous glint in her eye, “you are overcomplicating things. A gardener’s death is surely not the makings of a tragedy, unless you mean to undo the whole of our marriage on such a whim.”

The Major laughed, a rich, hearty sound that seemed to fill the room. “You are right, as always,” he conceded. “And yet, I cannot help but feel that Sommerville’s loss leaves a void—a reminder of the fragility of our... arrangements.”

“Well, then,” Mary said, standing and smoothing her skirts with a practiced gesture, “perhaps it is time to pay our respects to the man who once held such a peculiar place in our lives. A visit to his grave, a word of remembrance—what harm could that do?”

The Major’s eyes lit up with a rare flash of warmth. “Why, none at all,” he agreed. “And who knows? It may even restore your faith in the notion of a happily ever after.”

Mary rolled her eyes playfully. “Do not flatter yourself, Major. My faith in happily ever afters was never the issue. It was your peculiar obsession with gardeners that had me wondering.”

And with that, the two of them set off, the weight of the past momentarily lifted, their voices blending in a conversation that was as much about their shared history as it was about the future they had built together.

The believers in the weathercock tale, having misplaced their confidence once, were not easily prevailed upon to part with it again, so they looked as wise as they could, shrugged their shoulders, touched their foreheads, and murmured something about Gabriel Grub having drunk all the Hollands, and then fallen asleep on the flat tombstone; and they affected to explain what he supposed he had witnessed in the goblins' cavern, by saying that he had seen the world, and grown wiser. Mr. Dosson, it may further be noted, was a person of the simplest composition, a character as cipherable as a sum of two figures. He had a native financial faculty of the finest order, a gift as direct as a beautiful tenor voice, which had enabled him, without the aid of particular strength of will or keenness of ambition, to build up a large fortune while he was still of middle age. He had a genius for happy speculation, the quick unerring instinct of a “good thing”; and as he sat there idle amused contented, on the edge of the Parisian street, he might very well have passed for some rare performer who had sung his song or played his trick and had nothing to do till the next call. And he had grown rich not because he was ravenous or hard, but simply because he had an ear, not to term it a nose. He could make out the tune in the discord of the market-place; he could smell success far up the wind. The second factor in his little addition was that he was an unassuming father. He had no tastes, no acquirements, no curiosities, and his daughters represented all society for him. He thought much more and much oftener of these young ladies than of his bank-shares and railway-stock; they crowned much more his sense of accumulated property. He never compared them with other girls; he only compared his present self with what he would have been without them. His view of them was perfectly simple. Delia had a greater direct knowledge of life and Francie a wider acquaintance with literature and art. Mr. Dosson had not perhaps a full perception of his younger daughter’s beauty: he would scarcely have pretended to judge of that, more than he would of a valuable picture or vase, but he believed she was cultivated up to the eyes. He had a recollection of tremendous school-bills and, in later days, during their travels, of the way she was always leaving books behind her. Moreover wasn’t her French so good that he couldn’t understand it?

The two girls, at any rate, formed the breeze in his sail and the only directing determinant force he knew; when anything happened--and he was under the impression that things DID happen--they were there for it to have happened TO. Without them in short, as he felt, he would have been the tail without the kite. The wind rose and fell of course; there were lulls and there were gales; there were intervals during which he simply floated in quiet waters--cast anchor and waited. This appeared to be one of them now; but he could be patient, knowing that he should soon again inhale the brine and feel the dip of his prow. When his daughters were out for any time the occasion affected him as a “weather-breeder”--the wind would be then, as a kind of consequence, GOING to rise; but their now being out with a remarkably bright young man only sweetened the temporary calm. That belonged to their superior life, and Mr. Dosson never doubted that George M. Flack was remarkably bright. He represented the newspaper, and the newspaper for this man of genial assumptions represented--well, all other representations whatever. To know Delia and Francie thus attended by an editor or a correspondent was really to see them dancing in the central glow. This is doubtless why Mr. Dosson had slightly more than usual his air of recovering slowly from a pleasant surprise. The vision to which I allude hung before him, at a convenient distance, and melted into other bright confused aspects: reminiscences of Mr. Flack in other relations--on the ship, on the deck, at the hotel at Liverpool, and in the cars. Whitney Dosson was a loyal father, but he would have thought himself simple had he not had two or three strong convictions: one of which was that the children should never go out with a gentleman they hadn’t seen before. The sense of their having, and his having, seen Mr. Flack before was comfortable to him now: it made mere placidity of his personally foregoing the young man’s society in favour of Delia and Francie. He had not hitherto been perfectly satisfied that the streets and shops, the general immensity of Paris, were just the safest place for young ladies alone. But the company of a helpful gentleman ensured safety--a gentleman who would be helpful by the fact of his knowing so much and having it all right there. If a big newspaper told you everything there was in the world every morning, that was what a big newspaper-man would have to know, and Mr. Dosson had never supposed there was anything left to know when such voices as Mr. Flack’s and that of his organ had daily been heard. In the absence of such happy chances--and in one way or another they kept occurring--his girls might have seemed lonely, which was not the way he struck himself. They were his company but he scarcely theirs; it was as if they belonged to him more than he to them.

It was a Tuesday forenoon in the middle of April, 1813, a forenoon which unfolded with the delicate promise of a day devoted to gentle breezes and sun-dappled avenues—the kind of day when even the most hardened Parisian felt a fleeting pang of romance stir within their breast. The hour was striking eleven when a modest, yet meticulously maintained, tilbury, pulled by a single, well-groomed mare, emerged from the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré and ambled with a dignified pace onto the Place de la Concorde, halting near the foot of the scaffolding erected for the day's public spectacle. The occupant of the carriage, a man of perhaps forty years, bore the unmistakable mark of a life spent indoors, illuminated by the flickering glow of lamplight and consumed by the dusty embrace of books. His countenance, though intelligent, was pale and bore the faint etchings of worry; his attire, though undeniably of good quality, possessed a slightly unfashionable cut, as if tailored several seasons past.

From the far side of the carriage, the man alighted with a deliberate slowness, betraying a hint of stiffness in his joints. He then extended a gloved hand to assist his companion, a woman veiled against the dust and the prying eyes of the gathering crowd. As she descended, a collective murmur rippled through the onlookers, not for her beauty—though undoubtedly present, it was obscured by the veil—but for the palpable air of nervous energy that radiated from her very being. The woman, though seemingly composed, fidgeted with the clasp of her reticule, her gaze darting restlessly towards the formidable structure that dominated the square. "Are you certain, Thérèse," the man inquired, his voice laced with a mixture of concern and resignation, "that this…this spectacle is truly necessary? I confess, my dear, I find the prospect rather distasteful." Thérèse, however, offered no verbal reply, only a slight inclination of her veiled head, a gesture that conveyed both resolve and an unspoken plea for understanding. The man sighed, a wisp of vapor escaping his lips in the cool morning air. "Very well," he conceded, his tone tinged with defeat, "but I insist that we remain at a discreet distance. I have no desire to become entangled in the…enthusiasm of the mob."

The pair proceeded, at a measured pace, towards the periphery of the gathering crowd, their progress hampered by the throng of eager spectators vying for the best vantage point. Merchants, laborers, and even a smattering of elegantly dressed members of the aristocracy jostled shoulder-to-shoulder, their faces alight with anticipation. Thérèse, however, seemed oblivious to the swirling sea of humanity around her, her attention fixed solely upon the looming scaffold. She paused, momentarily, as a hawker, pushing his way through the crowd, loudly proclaimed the virtues of his "genuine souvenir ribbons, blessed by the very hand of the executioner!" The man recoiled in disgust, steering Thérèse sharply away from the peddler's path. "Such vulgarity!" he muttered under his breath. "Can these people truly find enjoyment in such barbarity?" Thérèse, once again, remained silent, her grip on her companion's arm tightening almost imperceptibly. Her eyes, visible now only as fleeting glimpses beneath the dark veil, betrayed a depth of emotion that the man found both unsettling and profoundly moving.

As they finally reached a relatively secluded corner, shielded somewhat by a large oak tree, Thérèse stopped abruptly. She raised a gloved hand, as if to ward off the scene before her. The man, sensing her distress, placed a comforting hand upon her arm. "Thérèse, my dear, if this is too much…" he began, but his words were cut short by a sudden hush that fell over the crowd. A drum roll, sharp and insistent, echoed across the square, followed by the sonorous tones of a town crier announcing the arrival of the condemned. Thérèse gasped, her body trembling violently beneath the folds of her gown. And as the unfortunate soul was led, manacled and pale, onto the platform, a single tear escaped from beneath Thérèse's veil and traced a glistening path down her cheek, a tear that spoke volumes of a secret burden carried, a burden that threatened to shatter the fragile composure she had so carefully maintained.

With this end in view, he established a small school in the village, where children from impoverished families could learn to read and write, to master the rudiments of arithmetic, and to acquire the basic skills necessary for various trades. And he kept a watchful eye on their progress, offering guidance and support, and celebrating their successes as if they were his own. “I don't believe in fairies. I never see any.” “Ha!” said his father.

“Mum said so.”
